My sincere apologies, Mr. Sifton: For far too long, I have been crediting your Pizza Cognition Theory to Adam Kuban and his colleagures at www.seriouseats.com (ans subsite, SLICE). During a recent private exchange, later very public, Mr. Kuban declined my acolades and again reminded this wide audience that PCT was your creation. While Mr. Kuban and his readers often cite PCT in countless discussions, it nice to finally know the origin.
Does PCT have merit? Hell Yes! I suspect that OCT has for more relevance then you knew, when you first expressed it. If you remember the encounter, apparently with Ed Livine, perhaps you can recall whether it was a seriously considered comment, or light humor. Do you? In the interveneing years, PCT has taken on some weight of its own and acquired considerable traction. I for one believe that your theory both serious and of remarkable insight. As I push 60, and with some 45+ years of serious eating experience in hand, including the odd pizza in 15+ countries and countless American 'joints,' as well as my own kitchen, hell yes! I am still sort of trying to recreate something close to my first 'cognitive' pizza, from roughly 1964. To date, I've come close, but no cigar.
To be sure, the world now includes much better (and much worse) pizza than I ate in '64. I know know enough about making the stuff that the '64 pie is not really an ideal target, yet I would eat it again, in an instant! In my never humble opinion, PCT is a very real thing. WHile PCT may no longer produce the target, it is a perfectly leitmate point of reference and one that I will never lose. I guess I am a middle-of the-road pizza guy: I do not eat (and detenst) manufactured/frozen/mass-market pies just as much as I ignore the Neo-Neapolitain craze of burned crust, too much bread and whimpy tops, perhaps graced with two basil leaves, especially those in teh $18-$35 range. Good Pizza is FUN, not prissy! Thanks again for creating and expressing the original of PCT.
Cedarglen

The law should prevail-- bar/pub owners' licenses and livelihoods depend on them.

It's not always clear whether the law applies though. Is a bar/pub that serves reheated pizza a restaurant? My wife and I got ejected from one such place--after buying our pints--because we'd brought our sleeping 1-year-old in his stroller to what we thought was a pub at 3 in the afternoon. We'd never have brought him to a busy bar during real drinking hours. A grouchy regular ratted us out and we were ordered to leave. The legal drinking age was invoked and nobody was friendly about it. I understand the barman's perspective--the dipso could be counted on to buy drink after drink, day after day-- but I'm damned if that pub is ever seeing a dollar from me again.

There are bars and there are bars.  And there are children and there are children.  And, for that matter, there are parents and there are parents.  A nice quiet bar, where people are going to behave themselves and not get rowdy should be able to tolerate a nice, quiet, well-behaved child, with parents who will do what they should if the child gets restless and noisy, which is take them out.  A rowdier bar, poorly behaved children and parents who don't exercise their parental responsibilities is a bad combination.

But I agree that crying babies do not belong in bars - or anywhere that they can disturb other people.

In Brazil, when you arrive at a social or many work gatherings (from a handful of people to a mini-mass of people), you are expected to greet and kiss or two on the cheek everyone, even those you are seeing for the first time in your life. Same process when you leave, if you leave before others. It can be tedious, and people often do it out of obligation. But to NOT do this greeting/farewell process is to be accused of "sair a francesa," of being selfish, of not being a warm person.

I think Josko wants botrytis to give his wines even more minerality, complexity and elegance. He made many experiments to deliberately have botrytis on his grapes (as far as I know) and since 2004 has been able to do so more or less consistently, I think.

Funny, I never really gave it much thought when I took my baby into a bar. We were traveling and walking around the town in Belgium with friends, who were natives. It was a cold blustery November afternoon and my 1 year old son fell asleep in the stroller. We walked past a charming bar with a great beer selection and snacks. It seemed like a good idea - to sit down, have a beer and a light snack in the afternoon and to get out of the cold for a bit. We sat and drank as the child slept and bothered no one, although the place was pretty empty. The staff didn't seem to mind and our friends were fine with it. What's the big deal?

I think parents should just be mindful. Don't bring kids in to a crowded bar and then have them get bored and run about disturbing people. Crying babies shouldn't be there, either. It all depends on the child, the bar, and the circumstances. It's not always acceptable or never appropriate. Just use common sense and show consideration - a bar is a place for adults, first and foremost. If the child isn't bothering anyone and no one seems to mind, then it's no big deal.

Mr. Wells, welcome to the side of good! I'm heartened that other readers don't bother with mise. They shouldn't--as you say, it's a restaurant technique, and I consider it one that's usually counterproductive in the home kitchen. I think it's a major shame that people learning to cook today are often taught unnecessary restaurant techniques--it makes cooking seem way too complex, rigid and messy (all those wee bowls!).

In my cookbook, Forking Fantastic!, published last year, my coauthor and I took the no-mise approach that Sarah Moulton does. Our recipes list ingredients, untouched, then describe what to do with them in the instructions. It's not rocket science--it just describes the most practical way of using your time in the kitchen. And, if you read enough recipes like this, you'll be a better, more efficient home cook.

Last year, I also did a podcast based on this no-mise idea. It's called Cooking in Real Time (www.cookinginrealtime.com), and each episode covers the preparation of a meal, showing how you can step back and forth between stove and cutting board. It helps to train your ears and nose to tell you what's going on when you're not at the stove.

Good luck, new cooks! Shake off the shackles of mise en place!
